title: 106_hr1606
content: The "FERS Buyback Act of 1999" is cited as the short title. The act addresses the creditability of service. The "FERS Buyback Act of 1999" amends Section 8411(b) of title 5, United States Code to include service as a temporary or intermittent employee performed between December 31, 1988, and January 1, 1999, of at least 1 year's duration, if the individual later becomes subject to this chapter. The "FERS Buyback Act of 1999" requires employees or Members to deposit 1.3 percent of basic pay for service as a temporary or intermittent employee between December 31, 1988, and January 1, 1999. Any deposit made more than 5 years after becoming an employee or Member must include interest. If the deposit is not made within 5 years, the service will still be creditable but the annuity will be reduced. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO PERSONS WHO HAVE SEPARATED. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for obtaining credit for service performed by individuals who have separated from Government service. Credit will only be given upon submission of a written application by December 31, 2001. Any annuity or survivor annuity will be recomputed to include the service described in the regulations. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for obtaining credit for service performed by individuals who have separated from Government service. Credit will only be given upon submission of a written application by December 31, 2001. An appropriate reduction will be made in the recomputed annuity if the full deposit required under section 8411(i) of title 5 is not timely made. Interest will not be included as part of any deposit under this subsection. SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION AND OTHER DUTIES OF THE OFFICE OF PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT. The Office of Personnel Management is required to inform individuals of their rights under the Act, assist in obtaining necessary information for service credits or annuity recomputations, and request information from relevant government entities regarding an individual's service history.
